name: Marvel Deaths Quiz | Marvel Comics | 10 Questions

questions.text: The X-Men's Colossus died to help the world find a cure for what deadly disease?
questions.explanation:
Legacy Virus.

	Colossus sacrificed himself to assist Beast's everlasting desire to find a cure for the virus now affecting humans, not just mutants.

questions.text: Former Avenger (for about 2 months) YellowJacket II died at the hands of what 'then-crazed' Avenger?
questions.explanation:
Iron Man.

	This crazed Iron Man would later be vanquished by a younger version of himself in one of the worst plots of all time.

questions.text: The Kree Intergalactic Superhero known as Captain Marvel (aka Mar-Vell) succumbed to an early demise from which of the following?
options: Thanos' mad quest for the Infinity Gems
Quasar's insane journey to gain the nega-bands
questions.explanation:
Inoperable Cancer.

	In one of the most touching moments in comic history, Captain Marvel died with nearly every Marvel superhero at his side.

questions.text: Wonder Man has had 2 'deaths' in the Marvel Universe, eventually returning to life from both.  How did he die the second time?
questions.correct: Within a massive explosion while aboard a Kree Warship
options: At the hands of the man who gave him his ionic powers, Baron Zemo
Fighting alongside the Avengers during the Intergalactic Storm
Stopping the evil Vision from destroying the Avengers
questions.explanation:
Within a massive explosion while aboard a Kree Warship.

	Wonder Man sure is resilient, isn't he folks?  He is kinda like the Energizer Bunny...he keeps going, and going, and going...

questions.text: Bobbi Morse, was once-known as what costumed crime-fighter?
questions.explanation:
Mockingbird.

	Mockingbird passed away while fighting in the West Coast Avengers last battle.  The Avengers West Coast disbanded at Captain America's request and the remaining members went on to form the short-lived Force Works.

questions.text: The oh, so pathetic Thunderbird I (John Proudstar) died on which of the following missions with the X-Men?
options: The 1st mission w/ Wolverine, Colossus, Storm, Nightcrawler, Sunfire, and Cyclops.
questions.explanation:
The 2nd Mission.

	Thunderbird, we all know him as "X-Men Cannon Fodder."  He was created solely for the purpose of killing off extremely quickly.

questions.text: Warren Worthington the III, better known as Angel, died and was brought back to life by Apocalypse.  How did he pass away?
questions.correct: He died in his private plane.
options: He sacrificed himself while in battle with X-Factor.
Wolverine's insane rage finally got the better of him.
questions.explanation:
He died in his private plane.

	After the loss of his wings during the Morlock slaughter, Warren no longer felt the will to live.

questions.text: True or False: there have been four Spider-Women, with the intent of fighting crime?
questions.explanation:
False.

	Jessica Drew, was the original Spider-Woman later becoming a detective in Madripoor.  Julia Carpenter, was the next don take up the mantle of Spider-Woman first appearring during the original Secret Wars confrontation (if it's so secret, how come we all know about it).  Mattie Franklin gained her Spider-Woman powers during the 'gathering of five', and even attempted fill Spider-Man's shoes for a while. May Parker, 'SPIDER-GIRL' (did I fool you) is a part of the MC2 Marvel Universe. There was also a fourth Spider-Woman who was a villian to the newest Spider-Woman (first appearance was in Spider-Woman Vol. 1 Issue 1).

questions.text: In the entire Marvel Universe, which is the only character listed below, never to have returned from the grave?
options: The Avengers' Wonder Man (duh! look at number 4).

questions.text: An X-Man perished in battle in the pages of X-Treme X-Men.  Who was that Character?
options: Thunderbird III (wow, there's been 3 of these guys, doesn't sound like the name is good luck).
questions.explanation:
Psylocke.

	Psylocke, poor, poor Psylocke.  Except for Chris Claremont, I do not think a single writer liked you.  Irony is, Chris Claremont acutally wrote your demise.
